text: Silence, except for the whisper of the wind. A WHITE SCREEN resolves into a wide view of a 19th centur cemetery, its dark contours softened by several inches of fresh snow. Big, wet flakes float down from a leaden sky. Wealthy MOURNERS stand under black umbrellas at an open grave as pallbearers slide a gleaming ebony coffin from a horse-drawn hearse. A legend FADES ON:

CAMERA DESCENDS to find a solemn, bespectacled child, EDI CUSHING, age 10, in a black coat and hat. Her delicate features are half-hidden behind a mourning veil. Frightened, the child clings to the gloved hand of her ta bearded father (CARTER CUSHING, 48). *
The first time I saw a ghost, I was ten. It was my Mother's- * The coffin passes before the child's pale face.

At that age, I barely understood what had happened. She had died of Cholera- * (beat) And on account of her disease, Father * ordered that the casket remain closed... As the coffin is lowered unto the earth- *

A coffin-like grandfather clock is TICKING in an enormous gas-lit bedroom. Shadows seem to swallow up the girl's * collection of dolls and books. Snowflakes drift past the tall windows, little Edith lies bed, staring at the wall. Her EYEGLASSES are on the bedsi table. (CONTINUED)

.--.So there was really no last glimpse. No goodbye. (pause) That is, until she came back. The clock stops ticking, the gas lamps go dark and the floorboards CREAK. There's a rustle of silk as- - a translucent tracery of cobweb ectoplasm crosses the room, its desiccated feet not touching the ground. The bed curtains move and the bedsprings sink down. Edith freezes, her eyes wide, her head turned away. She hears a low, asthmatic sigh. A shimmering hand caresses the child's hair. Finger bones are visible. In the dark, a glimpse of a tormented face..
-.-and I heard her voice. A throatless whisper, low and grave and full of earth. Her words seared my memory as if with fire...

Edith... beware of Crimson Peak. Crying out, the child sits up and looks around. Without h glasses, the world is a blur. A HAZY FIGURE is floating away. Edith puts on her glasses No one is there. The gas lamps come back on; the clock resumes its ticking.

Then she was gone. (pause) It would be years before I again heard a voice like that - or saw a dead thing come to life. But see it I did... and the horror hidden in her whispered warning would change my life forever.
A perfect spring day in Boston. The gorgeous blue sky is dotted with puffy white clouds... (CONTINUED)
---and below it, a city is growing.

1900 A new century has arrived and the teeming streets are ali with motorcars, bicycles and horse-drawn carriages. CAMERA FOLLOWS a veiled YOUNG WOMAN as she passes workmen paving streets and erecting power poles. Steam erupts fro pile driver... smoke roils from vats of hot tar. The young woman reaches the front door of a tea room. It' EDITH, now a pale but striking 22 year-old. She still wea glasses.

Sitting alone among the elegant PATRONS, Edith leafs thro a thick, handwritten MANUSCRIPT, making last-minute corrections. At the next table, the dowager MRS. WALKER and her chubby daughter EUNICE are gossiping with a group of vivacious women.
We met him at the British Museum. Last fall. He took one look at Eunice and said she was as beautiful as anything by- by-
Burne-Something- a painter- I think- (beat) Oh, mother, he is so handsome!
He never took his eyes off you, did he?
(barely able to get a word in) Well-
(overlapping) -Then we all went to tea. It seems he's a Baronet—
What's a Baronet?? (CONTINUED)
Edith closes her book and looks at Society Girl 1.
A Baronet is a minor aristocrat. An opportunist. A man who lives off land that others work for him.
Is that so, Edith?
That is so.
Well, from what I hear, this minor aristocrat is perfectly charming and is a great dancer...
...who's crossed the ocean with his sister. I'm sure it's because of Eunice. He's been writing us every week.
Mother, he's here on business!
I'm hearing wedding bells. But that wouldn't concern you, would it, Edith?
No, it wouldn't. Edith takes off her glasses and gets up to leave. Her dre and scarf are a sombre black and navy blue silk.
I think it's a shame, Edith, I really do! A man will never notice you if your nose is buried in books.
Wearing black and writing all day long - our very own Jane Austen.
(walking away) Thank you, Sally. But I would prefer Mary Shelley. And, Eunice? You don't look at all like a Burne-Jones. Not languid enough.

An enormous LOBBY, bustling with activity. Carrying her Manuscript, Edith approaches a reception desk where a GUA directs her to an elevator. CAMERA LINGERS on a STATUE of man, pensive and reading, surrounded by a pile of books. This is a likeness of MR. OGILVIE.
In the same exact position as the statue, SAMUEL OGILVIE grunts with displeasure as he leafs through Edith's work. Edith discreetly uses her glasses to see what page he's o
Hrumpf- Ogilvie pointedly turns his chair around and reads some more. Finally, he puts the manuscript down. He nods slowly, replacing it in the pouch.
So... Miss Cushing. How is your father? Now Edith knows what he thinks of her manuscript.
I take it he said no.
A beautiful dining room, with damask wallpaper and art nouveau sconces. Edith sits across from her FATHER, CARTE CUSHING (almost 60 now.) His beard is streaked with gray.
After skimming a single chapter, Father.
Ogilvie's old-fashioned. He probably looks down on ghost stories.
It's not a ghost story. (CONTINUED)
But it has a ghost in it-
Father. It's a... conduit- (off her father's look) -a pretext, to talk about spirituality. The ghost acts as a metaphor-
Ah. A metaphor. That may be too sophisticated for me, then-
Ogilvie said it needed a love story. Can you believe that?
Well... does it?
What?
Need a love story?
No!- Why? Why must a woman always write about love? Stories of girls in search of the ideal husband - or the man who eludes them?? Is there nothing else? Her father stares at her blankly.
I agree. Obviously he does not. At that moment, a WHISTLE from a passing train... anda train's lights move on the sheer curtains. Obeying an old habit, Cushing checks his POCKET WATCH - and smiles.
I'll have a word with Ogilvie- Monday at the club. She pulls the manuscript from the envelope.
You will not. (CONTINUED)
Why? Why won't you let me help you?
No- * (beat) * I have to do it myself. With my words on the page! Since I'm not "beautiful" - or "graceful" - or "charming"...
But you are!
The words have to do it. All I have are * words... and they will find their way into print. You'll see. In the meantime you just have to hear me complain... He smiles and pats his daughter's cheek.
With pleasure, always.
A high, wide view of a RAILYARD with steam locomotives chuffing from a roundhouse. CAMERA PANS to a five-storey brick OFFICE BUILDING. *
In the large, busy outer office, a scowling Edith is sitt at someone's desk, fingers pecking on a newfangled Underw typewriter.
JANE, a gray-haired secretary, is showing her how to use
See? The carriage return is almost automatic. Just push this lever here-
Automatic. Such a horrid word, isn't it? Everything is automatic now... But - (looking at the page) -it does look stronger than longhand. (CONTINUED)
It's a diabolical contraption, but if you're writing to publishers, you'll get their attention. And you'll save time, I warrant.

I'm not sure I want to save time at all. What would I do with it? THOMAS SHARPE, 38, enters. He's a well-dressed, handsome Englishman and carries a WALKING STICK and a MAHOGANY BOX Edith is too engrossed in her letter to notice him.
(to Edith) Good morning, Miss. Wham! - Edith bangs over the carriage return and looks up Sharpe blushes and removes his hat.
Sorry to interrupt, but I have an appointment with Mr. Carter Everett Cushing. Esquire.
Goodness. With the great man, himself?
I'm afraid so.
I'm sorry, but I'm the- Edith signals her to be quiet. She'll handle this.
You're not late, are you? He hates that.
In fact, I'ma bit early.
Oh - I'm afraid he hates that, too. Sharpe leans a bit closer.
Pardon me for asking, but - is he really as terrible as they say? Edith glances at Jane and smiles. (CONTINUED)
Sharpe turns extended. He holds the
A monster.
I don't believe it. Why would a pair of charming ladies work for such a person?
He pays me nothing.
(chuckles) True enough-
Impossible. Where is this fiend? I shall make it my business to protest, to rebuke him-
He's just behind you, sir. to find Carter Cushing approaching, hand
Sir Thomas Sharpe. Welcome to Boston. young man's hand an extra moment- He regards Sharpe's long, wavy hair, his walking stick an velvet-collared suit.
(gestures toward Edith) May I introduce Edith, my daughter- Sharpe is speechless.

We've just met, father. (to Sharpe) It was a pleasure to make your acquaintance, Sir Thomas. I hope the great man treats you well. She smiles sweetly at Sharpe, who looks abashed but pleas  10. INT. CONFERENCE ROOM — DAY The conference room overlooks the railyard. A dozen BANKE and INVESTORS sit at Cushing's table. Amongst them, an elderly attorney - WILLIAM FERGUSON. Sharpe's mahogany box rests near a stack of topographical maps and production charts. Alongside, a small alcohol la heats a miniature, nickel-plated boiler. He shows the from hand to
In the last few years, we scraped together just enough capital to reopen the mines and find what we believe are very encouraging samples. men a rough hunk of iron ore. As they pass it hand...
"We," you say? Who might that be?
Mining engineers. Geologists. I have their statements here-
So- you've never done any digging yourself? (beat) In that mountain of yours?
I'm afraid not. Cushing looks at the others: "Thought so." He opens the
Go on.
As investors in mining, you'll want more than speculation and projections. So here, gentlemen- box to reveal a SCALE MODEL of a mining drill.
-a steam drill - my own design - that matches the output of a ten-man crew. With mechanized digging, abandoned mines can be reworked and made profitable again. (CONTINUED)
He connects the little boiler. With a HISS of steam, the brass levers and gears start moving; the drill spins. The men admire its ingenuity - all except Cushing.
Turn that off, please. Sudden silence as Sharpe complies.
So you come to us, having failed to raise capital in London. The Boston businessmen glance at Cushing, whose cold smil reflects open skepticism.
London, Edinburgh, Leipzig -
Where your family name seems to have counted for very little. The door to the conference room is ajar. Edith stands the half-hidden, peeking in like a child.
I'm not discussing my name. This is a new century. As a railroad man, you'll need steel-
We have no shortage of iron ore in this country. Your holdings came to you through inheritance, did they not?
All right, yes. My great grandfather was Lord Middleton Sharpe, first Baronet of Allerdale. But the Sharpe Mines are more than a name, sir. More than nostalgia. They are my birthright.
And now Thomas Sharpe the Baronet -— you've come to America, where you hope to raise money to honor that birthright?
In part, yes. (CONTINUED)

In this country, we don't have such traditions. The men at this table - all of us - we came up through honest, hard work. Well- almost all of us - Mr. Ferguson here is an attorney, but he can't help that-— Laughter amongst the men.
But- his father shined and repaired shoes. As for me, I started out laying those very tracks - there in the yards below - decades ago. You see? And my hands- He raises two thick, calloused hands.
-reflect who I am. Just as yours do. Softest handshake I've felt in years. (beat) We bank on effort, not privilege. Sharpe surveys at the faces of the other men, now stern a uncomfortable.
(touching the model drill) I believe that inventions like this are equal to any man's hard work. I make no apology for my dreams... A TRAIN puffs by in the railyard. Cushing checks his pock watch.
(without looking up) Take your toy, young man, and dream somewhere else.
Mr. Cushing, I have tried to be as frank as possible, but you've not given me a fair hearing.
No? Well, you may attribute it toa Yank's lack of breeding. Sharpe is devastated but silent. (CONTINUED)
I knew just how he felt, this fellow dreamer, when I saw him facing defeat. Sharpe turns and meets Edith's eyes. She darts out of sig

Edith sits at her desk, writing in her diary. Behind her, a framed CHILD'S DRAWING of a ruddy mountain thrusting up into a blue-black sky. The schoolgirl letter beneath it reads: C-R-I-M-S-O-N P-E-A-K. The room is a bohemian hodgepodge of books, paintings, ru and tapestries.
Over the next few days, Sir Thomas Sharpe walked the muddy, torn-up streets of Boston in search of an investor. I, meanwhile, had found inspiration.

Edith stealthily follows Thomas Sharpe through a series o rejections: AT THE BANK, she observes through an open door. AT A GENTLEMANS' CLUB she peers through a window. AT A MEETING HALL he is, again, sent away.

I would rethink my book. I would try my hand at romance after all. For the first time the genre appealed to me. Sharpe finally reaches a deserted alley. Exhausted and furious, he throws down his papers and the mahogany box. Once he's gone, Edith steps out from hiding and looks at smashed MINIATURE and the multitude of gears spilled on t ground.  14.
At the mirror in his front hall, Carter Cushing checks hi white tie and tails. As a SERVANT brings him his hat and coat, Edith enters, wearing a simple house dress.
I do wish you'd change your mind and come along. It's not just another party. Not that there's anything wrong with a simple party, mind you.
You know I can't bear such things.
There's a performance of some kind, a woman's playing Chopin. Or is it Ravel..? I can't keep ‘em straight. (pause) And little Lord Fauntleroy will be there.
You mean Thomas Sharpe?
None other. I saw you spying on us, child.
I found him interesting, it's true. Like a character, in a play.
A bad actor, you mean. Nothing to swoon about.
Nobody's swooning. But tell me: were his ideas so outrageous as to merit such a quick dismissal?

It wasn't his ideas, my love. I felt a lack of focus. Is he the inventor of a steam drill? Or a mine owner seeking to exploit his holdings? There's something ill-defined about him; you can't do business with men like that. The DOORBELL rings. (CONTINUED)
That'll be young Dr. McMichael. He's brought his new motorcar. That's a good fellow- He's-
(rolls her eyes) I know, Father- he's got such a firm handshake... The servant opens the door and shows in DR. ALAN McMICHAE 31, a serious, bearded internist. He, too, is in formal wear. Cushing dons
Good evening, Mr. Cushing. Hello, Edith...
Good evening, Alan. My, don't we look smart.
(blushing) Not really. No more than your average penguin.
It's Edith who should be the belle of the ball, don't you agree, Doctor?
(gazing at her) Change your mind, Edith. With you, I could actually dance.

You lads will have much more fun without me. (to Dr. McMichael) Don't let him drink too much. (to her father) And no pontificating, brawling or flirting, either. No matter how fetching the ladies. his hat and coat.
I'll be a saint! (CONTINUED)
The old man chortles - Edith's the love of his life.
Edith sprawls on her bed, engrossed in a thick book reple with maps of England.

I was busy reading about iron mining in * the North of England. * Outside, RAINDROPS spatter the windows. Sharpe's half- assembled MINIATURE DRILL stands on the desk. Edith turns a page and stumbles upon an old engraving of mining operation in Cumberland.

And I found the Sharpe mines, in a barren landscape at the base of a mountain... * Outside, a distant RUMBLE of thunder. And behind her - th miniature steam drill tumbles off the desk and crashes to the floor. * Edith leaps to her feet. The mirrored door to an ARMOIRE
opens and something recedes into a darkness. Only the hem a dress is visible. Edith recognizes it.

(whisper) Mother-? She approaches the corner and descries the rippling shape a WOMAN - shadow upon shadow. A cadaverous FACE seems to emerge from the darkness, with enormous eyes, wet with tears. * As Edith suppresses a scream - a TAP on the door and a MA SERVANT leans in.
Excuse me, miss - Edith spins around, then glances back, seeing nothing now just a dark dress hanging in the armoir. * (CONTINUED)
Are you all right, miss? Whatever is the matter?
Nothing. You - you startled me, that's all.
There's a Thomas Sharpe at the door, he's * dripping wet and most insistent on coming in.
Thomas Sharpe? At this hour?? It's out of * the question, Annie. *

I told him, miss. He won't go away. * Edith dons a dressing gown and goes to the window overlooking the rainy courtyard. Thomas Sharpe stands at front door, holding an umbrella. He's wearing white tie a tails. She removes her glasses and opens the window.
Good evening, Mr. Sharpe. Father's not home, I'm sorry to say.
Of course he's not! He's gone - maybe by gondola - to the reception at the Walker house. Which is my destination, too
But that's in Roxbury. This is Back Bay. You're very much off course.
Not at all, my dear Miss Cushing. I've found you, haven't I? I don't think I can * brave the best of Boston society without you as my guide.
Miss Eunice Walker, I believe, will be waiting for you. With open arms. (CONTINUED)
The devil take Miss Eunice Walker! Please, am I to make a wretch of myself? Am I to beg- Sharpe kneels among the puddles.
I'm lost in a strange city. A child- a mere child. And I desperately need your help.
(smiling now) Help with what?
Well, the language, for one. As you see, I don't speak a word of American. Edith laughs. She glances back into the room, where Sharp model drill lies in pieces on the floor.
I don't know, Mr. Sharpe. Tonight's already been somewhat... strange. For whatever reason, I'm seeing things.
Wonderful! Come with me and we'll see them together.

All of Boston society is seated in a ballroom where a pia recital is underway. In the audience: Eunice Walker, her mother and Society Girls 1 & 2. At the keyboard is a striking blonde WOMAN with chiseled features and an intense air of concentration. This is LUCILLE SHARPE, 40, Thomas' sister. She concludes a brilliant Chopin Polonaise and stands to acknowledge the APPLAUSE. Eunice brings her an armful of roses; they exchange warm kisses to renewed applause and approving murmurs. Taking a final bow, Lucille's expression darkens: her brother has entered the room, accompanied by a transforme Edith. (CONTINUED)

A new BUZZ from the guests as they take notice. Edith is vision of understated elegance in pale blue satin. Seeing her on Sharpe's arm, Eunice Walker and her mother are crestfallen. Cushing leaves his seat and hurries over to his daughter. he acknowledges Sharpe...
I congratulate you, sir. Only remarkable .-.persistence could bring my daughter out of her cave.
Glad to be of service, Mr. Cushing. Like her father, she was not easily moved.
None of us are, Mr. Sharpe. What did he promise you, Edith?
Nothing, father. I'm just more pliable than you. Dr. McMichael approaches, dazzled by her appearance.
Hello, Alan. May I introduce Sir Thomas Sharpe? (to Sharpe) This is Dr. McMichael. The man to see in Boston if you're feeling poorly.
That's quite a glowing presentation, Edith-
He's brilliant. If you have aches and pains- Dr. McMichael lowers his head, even more disappointed at this.
But I've never felt better, Miss Cushing, thanks to you. (shaking the Doctor's hand) A pleasure to meet you, sir, under any circumstances. (CONTINUED)

Outside - a brief flicker of LIGHTNING... and more THUNDE rolls over the city. An exclamation from the crowd as the room GOES DARK. SERVANTS scurry to light candelabras, which give the room romantic and mysterious glow. The befuddled hostess, MRS. WALKER brings the beautiful blonde pianist over to them. But as she moves through the room, a shadow seems to follow... ---and within it Edith sees a pair of pinprick eyes glittering in a sallow face. She recoils, again recognizi the ghost of her mother. But the stout and imposing Mrs. Walker blocks her view.
Good evening, Sir Thomas, you honor us. Welcome to our fair city.
I'm sorry we're late. He kisses Mrs. Walker's hand.

Oh, a kiss. How very rare that is today. Eunice can't wait to say hello. (turning to Edith) Edith. What a surprise. Seeing you... sparkle. As the ghostly image of her mother blurs and rises toward the ceiling, a flustered Edith tries to collect herself. Lucille is watching her closely.
Our magnificent pianist is Lucille Sharpe, who's come with her brother all the way from Cumberland, in England- or is it Scotland?
Ah. That thorny question dates back to before the Norman conquest.
It's in Northern England, Mrs. Walker, made famous by Mr. Wordsworth. (CONTINUED)
Exactly, Miss Cushing. Although Dove Cottage is a long, long way from where we live. Mrs. Walker takes Sharpe by the arm and leads him away.

Eunice is here, Mr. Sharpe, waiting in the dark with her friends. They insist on hearing your wonderful accent. (beat) Of course, we've heard English accents before, but yours is so- so- very... Thomas is quickly surrounded by a cloud of excited young women. Eunice shoulders her way to the front of the pack. Edith's eyes apparition.
(to Edith) All that adoration. He positively basks in it. dart over the room, ready for another
Word travels quickly in Boston. Among the young females, anyway.
Do you not count yourself among them? Edith hears the woman's delicate sarcasm and finally turn to face her.

It is your brother, Miss Sharpe, who sought me out. Left to my own devices, I avoid parties like this and the waspish women who flourish here. A small string ORCHESTRA starts playing a stately passacaglia; floor. Thomas frees the servants clear the chairs from the dance himself from the girls and bows to Edith. Mrs. Walker and Eunice look on, losing all hope.
Miss Cushing. You came this far - will you venture a few steps further? (CONTINUED)
I'm not much of a dancer, Mr. Sharpe.
Could I be the judge of that?? He escorts her onto the dance floor...

...-where two concentric circles of GUESTS move rhythmica clockwise and counterclockwise. The steps are formal and controlled; each GUEST holds a LIT CANDLE. Sharpe grabs two candles — for Edith and one for himself. They join the outermost circle. All the while, Edith keeps a wary, distracted eye on the darkest corners. Sharpe is amused.
Miss Cushing. Whatever are you searching for? Here I am. Embarrassed, Edith gazes into his eyes.

I - I'm sorry. I told you I was seeing things tonight. The guests keep moving while the music lasts, each one guarding his or her flame jealously. Its a game, not unli "musical chairs." Suddenly the MUSIC stops. JOYOUS CHAOS. Everybody covers own candle while trying to blow out others! The last pers holding a lit candle will win. The two circles shrink accordingly. The dancing resumes.
Look at all those long faces. Eunice, my father... and your sister.

Lucille? She just likes to worry. Any girl who crosses my path - she stands guard. The music stops again and the circles shrink some more. N only four couples remain- amongst them SHARPE and EDITH. (CONTINUED)
Maybe it was a mistake, letting you drag me out here. Mrs. Walker looks furious-
Just close your eyes, then.
And if I close them, what? They won't see me?

Precisely. Won't you try it? Edith closes her eyes and lets Sharpe guide her round and round... until the music stops. More candles go out. Now only ONE couple remains: Sharpe and Edith. They start dancing again, staring into each other's eyes. The music ceases for the last time and -after a collectiv gasp- the room falls silent. Two flames left. WHAT WILL
Sharpe blows his own flame out and bows to Edith. She in turn blows out her candle... and the room explodes in applause!! Everybody is delighted. Everybody except MR. CUSHING. FADE OUT.
A SERVANT places a breakfast tray on a table in Edith's bedroom. Edith, in a dressing gown, is scribbling away, w a growing stack of manuscript pages at her elbow.

So, a new book took shape. All about a young man's quest to fulfill the legacy of a once-great family. I'd never thought much about the travails of the well-born. Fortunately, Sir Thomas delayed his departure, again and again... + eH (CONTINUED)
Edith puts down her pen, opens the heavy drapes, she lets the sunlight flood her room.
Edith and Sharpe are picnicking on the banks of the Charl River. As Sharpe reads a few pages of Edith's manuscript.
This fellow, "Cavendish" - your hero - has he no fears? No doubts?
Of course he does. He's haunted by his ancestors. You'll see.
Haunted? Literally?
No ghosts this time. I've banished them from my fiction. But they have visited me, they really have... He takes a snapshot of Edith with a KODAK BROWNIE BOX
At an exhibition of French Symbolist paintings, Edith and Sharpe stop to admire a strange, dreamlike work by Odilon Redon.

You've made a conquest, my dear, whether you know it or not. Proceed with caution, that's all I ask. Edith has resumed her typing, a pencil clenched between h teeth. Cushing studies her, aware of her happiness.
The greenhouse is an elegant edifice of glass and steel, lush with flowers. Edith smiles as TWO SERVANTS set out a afternoon tea on a table near the entrance.
